system-context-story.text: Students: The Users. Meet our users—students eager to learn software engineering. They access everything through a simple browser, connecting to our platform over standard HTTP.
Admins: The Managers. Admins manage the platform—creating courses, managing organizations, and monitoring learner progress. Same browser access, elevated permissions!
GitHub Pages Hosting. All requests flow through GitHub Pages. This CDN serves our static HTML files lightning-fast from edge locations worldwide. No server to manage!
Marketing Pages. Marketing pages are public—landing pages, course catalog, and pricing. No login required! Anyone can browse and discover what we offer.
Auth Pages. Auth pages handle login, registration, and password reset. This is where users become authenticated members of the platform.
Dashboard. The dashboard shows personalized progress—courses enrolled, completion percentages, learning velocity, and the cognitive score.
Lesson Pages. Lesson pages are where the magic happens. These interactive course content pages include quizzes, drag-drop activities, and progress tracking.
Blog. The blog features articles and tutorials. Some content is public, some requires login. A mix of marketing and education!
Shared JavaScript Services. All pages tap into our nine shared JavaScript services. These handle authentication, data storage, progress tracking, and more.
Firebase Authentication. Firebase Auth manages all user sessions. Email and password login, Google OAuth, password resets—it's all handled securely by Firebase.
Firestore Database. Finally, Firestore stores all user data—progress, quiz answers, notes, and more. Real-time sync keeps everything instantly up to date!

service-deps-story.text: FirebaseApp: The Foundation. Everything starts with FirebaseApp. This service initializes the Firebase SDK, giving all other services access to authentication and database.
AuthService Layer. AuthService wraps Firebase Auth with a clean API. It manages user sessions, login flows, and broadcasts auth state changes to the entire app.
DataService Operations. DataService is the workhorse. It needs both FirebaseApp for database access AND AuthService to scope every query to the current user.
RBACService. RBACService handles role-based access control. It checks if users have the right role and organization membership to access content.
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker watches what users scroll past using IntersectionObserver. It saves progress through DataService for the authenticated user.
ActivityTracker. ActivityTracker captures quiz answers and activity completions. Like ProgressTracker, it needs DataService and AuthService.
AnalyticsService. AnalyticsService calculates learning metrics—velocity, mastery, cognitive score. It reads data through DataService to compute these stats.
RouteGuard. RouteGuard protects pages that require login. It checks authentication status AND role permissions before showing any content.
LessonIntegration. LessonIntegration orchestrates everything on lesson pages. It coordinates AuthService, DataService, ProgressTracker, and ActivityTracker together!

data-flow-story.text: Browser: The Starting Point. Every journey begins in the browser. The user loads a page and starts interacting with buttons, forms, and scrollable content.
HTML Page Loads. The browser loads a static HTML page. This includes all the structure, styles, and JavaScript files needed to make it interactive.
UI Components Render. The HTML page renders interactive UI components—buttons, progress bars, quiz options. These are the touchpoints users interact with.
Event Handlers Fire. When users click, scroll, or type, event handlers spring into action. These JavaScript functions decide what happens next.
Services Process. Event handlers call service methods. This is where business logic lives—never in UI code. Services validate, transform, and route data.
State Management. Services update local state—window globals and component state. This triggers UI re-renders to show the latest data.
Firebase SDK. Services communicate with Firebase through the client-side SDK. It handles authentication tokens and database connections automatically.
Firestore Database. The Firebase SDK writes to Firestore in the cloud. Progress saved, quiz answers recorded, notes stored—all persisted permanently.
LocalStorage Cache. Some data is cached in LocalStorage for offline access and faster loading. This reduces database reads and improves performance!

page-services-story.text: Marketing Pages. Marketing pages are the lightest. They only load the navbar script for basic navigation. No authentication needed—anyone can browse!
navbar.js. navbar.js is the simplest service—just navigation handling. It's the only script marketing pages need to load!
Auth Pages. Login and register pages need more than navigation. They load AuthService for credential validation and account creation.
auth.js. auth.js handles all authentication—email login, Google OAuth, password reset, and session management. Many pages depend on it!
Dashboard. The dashboard is where users see their progress. It needs auth, data, analytics, and route protection—four services!
data-service.js. data-service.js handles all Firestore operations. Progress, activities, notes—anything that needs to persist goes through here.
analytics-service.js. analytics-service.js calculates learning metrics. Velocity, mastery, cognitive score—all the numbers on your dashboard!
route-guard.js. route-guard.js protects pages requiring login. If you're not authenticated, you get redirected before seeing anything.
Lesson Pages. Lesson pages are feature-rich! They need the most services—progress tracking, activity tracking, lesson orchestration, and more.
progress-tracker.js. progress-tracker.js uses IntersectionObserver to track what sections you've scrolled past. It auto-saves your reading progress!
activity-tracker.js. activity-tracker.js captures quiz answers and activity completions. Every interaction is logged for learning analytics.
lesson-integration.js. lesson-integration.js orchestrates everything on lesson pages. It coordinates all the trackers and services together!
Blog Pages. Blog pages are mostly public but can have some interactive features. They load navbar and the blog-specific service.
blog.js. blog.js handles blog-specific features—interactive elements, code highlighting, and optional auth for premium content.
Partner Courses. Partner courses are like lesson pages plus access control. Users must belong to the right organization to view content.
rbac.js. rbac.js checks organization membership and course access. Without the right permissions, you can't see partner content!

init-sequence-story.text: FirebaseApp.init(). The initialization chain begins! FirebaseApp.init runs first, setting up the Firebase SDK and making the database available to all other services.
AuthService.init(). Next, AuthService.init sets up the auth state listener. This tracks login status and notifies the app when users sign in or out.
DataService Ready. With auth ready, DataService becomes available. It can now query the database using FirebaseApp.getDb() for the authenticated user.
RBACService Ready. RBACService initializes in parallel with DataService. It needs both auth and database access to check user roles and permissions.
RouteGuard.init(). RouteGuard waits for both DataService and RBACService. It checks page access permissions and redirects unauthorized users.
ProgressTracker.init(). ProgressTracker.init sets up scroll observation using IntersectionObserver. It tracks which sections the user has viewed.
ActivityTracker.init(). ActivityTracker.init discovers interactive activities on the page—quizzes, drag-drops, code challenges. Ready to capture user interactions!

auth-service-story.text: AuthService: The Hub. AuthService is the authentication hub. It wraps Firebase Auth with a clean, consistent API for the rest of the application to use.
register() Method. The register method creates new accounts. It validates input, calls Firebase, updates the profile with display name, and creates the user document.
loginWithEmail() Method. loginWithEmail handles traditional email and password authentication. Users enter their credentials and Firebase validates them securely.
loginWithGoogle() Method. loginWithGoogle opens the OAuth popup. One click and users are authenticated with their Google account. Fast and secure!
logout() Method. The logout method signs the user out of Firebase and clears all cached authentication state. Clean and simple!
currentUser Property. The currentUser property caches the authenticated user. Any component can check login status instantly without waiting for Firebase.
onAuthStateChanged(). onAuthStateChanged broadcasts login and logout events. Components subscribe to react when authentication status changes.
Firebase Auth Backend. Firebase Auth is the backend service that handles all the heavy lifting—password hashing, token generation, OAuth flows, and secure session management.
User Document. After registration, a user document is created in Firestore. This stores profile data, roles, and organization membership for the app to use.

data-service-story.text: DataService: Central Hub. DataService is the central data hub. All Firestore operations flow through here—progress, activities, notes, enrollments, and more.
Progress Operations. Progress ops handle lesson and course completion. saveLessonProgress, getCourseProgress—everything about tracking what users have learned.
Activity Operations. Activity ops record quiz answers, drag-drop completions, and code challenges. Every attempt is logged for analytics.
Enrollment Operations. Enrollment ops manage course registrations. Users enroll in courses, and the system tracks their enrollment status and access dates.
courseProgress Collection. courseProgress stores high-level course completion data. Percentage complete, last accessed timestamp, and overall course status.
lessonProgress Collection. lessonProgress tracks individual lessons. Which sections were viewed, time spent, scroll position, and completion status.
activityAttempts Collection. activityAttempts records every quiz answer and activity interaction. Timestamps, answers, scores—all preserved for learning analytics.

tracking-services-story.text: IntersectionObserver API. The browser's IntersectionObserver API powers scroll tracking. It efficiently detects when sections enter or leave the viewport.
DOM Events. DOM Events trigger activity tracking. Clicks, changes, and other user interactions fire events that ActivityTracker listens for.
ProgressTracker Service. ProgressTracker uses IntersectionObserver to watch sections. When 50 percent of a section is visible, it's marked as viewed.
ActivityTracker Service. ActivityTracker listens for DOM events—clicks on quiz options, drops in drag zones. Every interaction is captured and scored.
viewedSections Set. viewedSections is a Set that stores which sections have been scrolled to. It prevents duplicate tracking and enables efficient lookups.
completedActivities State. completedActivities tracks which activities the user has finished. It stores activity IDs and their completion states in memory.
lessonProgress Firestore. viewedSections data persists to Firestore's lessonProgress collection. Even if you close the browser, your progress is saved!
activityAttempts Firestore. Activity completion data flows to Firestore's activityAttempts collection. Every quiz answer and interaction is permanently recorded.

analytics-pipeline-story.text: Progress Data Input. Analytics starts with raw data—lesson completion records from Firestore. This tells us how much content users have consumed.
Activity Data Input. Quiz attempts and scores feed into the pipeline separately. This measures how well users understand the material, not just consumption.
calculateVelocity(). calculateVelocity computes learning speed. Lessons completed divided by weeks active, scaled to a 0-100 score. Fast learners score high!
calculateMastery(). calculateMastery averages quiz scores. Correct answers divided by total attempts gives us a mastery percentage.
Learning Velocity Score. Learning Velocity is the final speed metric. Lessons per week times 20, capped at 100. It shows how quickly a learner is progressing.
Quiz Mastery Score. Quiz Mastery shows understanding depth. High scores mean the learner truly grasps concepts, not just skimming through content.
calculateCognitive(). calculateCognitive combines all metrics! 40 percent mastery, 30 percent velocity, 20 percent streak, 10 percent completion. The formula for learning excellence!
Final Cognitive Score. The Cognitive Score is the ultimate learning metric. One number that represents overall learning effectiveness. Higher is better!

access-control-story.text: Page Request. A user wants to access a protected resource. Maybe a partner course or the admin dashboard. Let's see if they're allowed!
Authentication Check. First checkpoint—is the user signed in? No authentication means redirect to login. Can't proceed without credentials!
Redirect to Login. If the user isn't authenticated, they're redirected to the login page. After signing in, they'll return to where they wanted to go.
hasRole() Check. If authenticated, we check the user's role using hasRole(). Are they admin, enterprise, or standard user? Different roles unlock different resources.
belongsToOrg() Check. belongsToOrg() verifies organization membership. For partner courses, users must belong to the sponsoring organization.
canAccessCourse() Check. canAccessCourse() is the final gate. It verifies the user has permission to access this specific course content.
Access Granted!. All checks passed! The user can access the content. Page renders, learning begins. The flow is complete!

page-hierarchy-story.text: All Page Types. The SWE Hackers platform has ten distinct page types. They're organized by access requirements—from fully public to highly restricted.
Public Pages Category. Public pages need no authentication. Anyone can browse these without signing in.
Marketing Pages. Marketing includes landing pages, course catalog, and pricing. These attract new users with no barriers to entry.
Auth Pages. Auth pages handle login, registration, and password reset. They're public so users can create accounts and sign in.
Protected Pages Category. Protected pages require authentication. You must be logged in to see these!
Dashboard. The dashboard is your personal hub. It shows enrolled courses, progress metrics, and learning analytics.
Lesson Pages. Lesson pages are where the actual learning happens. Interactive content, quizzes, and progress tracking.
RBAC Protected Category. RBAC pages add role and organization checks on top of authentication. Extra security layers!
Partner Courses. Partner courses are organization-specific. You must belong to the sponsoring organization AND have course access.
Admin Pages. Admin pages require the admin role. Only platform administrators can access user management and system settings.

dashboard-flow-story.text: Page Load Begins. User navigates to the dashboard. The browser requests the page, and our loading sequence kicks into gear.
Show Loading Screen. First, we show a loading screen. Content is hidden until we confirm the user is authenticated. No flashing of unauthorized content!
Init Services. While the loading screen shows, services initialize—Firebase SDK, AuthService, and DataService get ready.
Auth Check. Services are ready! Now we check authentication. Is there a valid user session? If not, redirect to login.
Load User Profile. Auth confirmed! We fetch the user profile—display name, enrolled courses, preferences. This happens in parallel with analytics.
Load Analytics. Simultaneously, we calculate learning metrics—velocity, mastery, streak, cognitive score. All computed from progress data.
Stats Cards Render. Analytics flow to the stats cards. Velocity, mastery, and streak scores render with animated progress indicators.
Course Grid Render. User profile data populates the course grid. Each enrolled course shows progress percentage and last activity date.

lesson-architecture-story.text: LessonIntegration Orchestrator. LessonIntegration orchestrates everything on lesson pages. It coordinates progress tracking, activity handling, and UI updates.
Scroll Events. As users scroll, browser events fire. These scroll events trigger the progress tracking system.
ProgressTracker Service. ProgressTracker uses IntersectionObserver for efficient scroll detection. When 50 percent of a section is visible, it counts as viewed.
Save Progress. Progress changes trigger Firestore writes. Your reading progress is persisted so you can pick up where you left off.
Progress Bar Updates. The progress bar updates in real-time as you scroll. Visual feedback shows exactly how much of the lesson you've covered.
Quiz Click Events. When you click a quiz answer, interaction events fire. Time to validate your knowledge!
lesson.js UI Handler. lesson.js handles the UI side of interactions—showing feedback, highlighting correct answers, playing animations.
ActivityTracker Service. ActivityTracker handles all interactive elements—quizzes, drag-drop, code challenges. Every completion is saved to Firestore.
Lesson Complete Toast. When progress hits 90 percent, the lesson is marked complete. A celebration toast appears, and the next lesson unlocks!

partner-flow-story.text: Course Request. A user tries to access a partner course. These are organization-specific—not everyone can get in. Let's check the credentials!
Auth Check Gate. First gate—authentication. Is the user logged in? If not, we redirect to login.
Redirect to Login. No authentication? Redirect to login! After signing in, the user will return to try again.
Load Permissions. User is authenticated! Now we fetch their RBAC data—roles, organization memberships, and course access lists.
Organization Check. Second gate—organization membership. The user must belong to the organization that sponsors this course.
Course Access Check. Final gate—course access. Does the user have this specific course in their access list? All gates cleared means access granted!
Access Granted - Render. All checks passed! The lesson content renders. Learning begins. The multi-layer security keeps content protected.

collection-hierarchy-story.text: Firestore Root. Welcome to Firestore—our cloud database! It uses a hierarchical structure with collections, documents, and nested subcollections.
Users Collection. The users collection is our main entry point. Every registered user gets a document here, identified by their Firebase Auth UID.
Courses Collection. The courses collection stores course metadata. This is optional—mainly used for admin features and catalog displays.
User Document. Each user document stores profile info, role, and organization memberships. But that's just the start—subcollections hold the real data!
Course Progress. The courseProgress subcollection tracks progress per course. Each course the user enrolls in gets its own document here.
Daily Challenges. dailyChallenges tracks completed challenges by date. This powers the streak calculation and daily engagement metrics.
User Notes. The notes subcollection stores user notes per lesson. Personal annotations that persist across sessions.
Course Document. Each course progress document contains summary data plus nested subcollections for detailed tracking.
Lesson Progress. Nested even deeper—lessonProgress tracks individual lessons. Viewed sections, completion status, last visit time. Granular tracking!
Activity Attempts. Every quiz answer, drag-drop completion, and code challenge is recorded in activityAttempts. Complete history of engagement!
Lesson Document. Each lesson document stores detailed progress—viewed sections array, timestamps, scroll position, and completion percentage.
Attempt Document. Individual attempt documents record each interaction—timestamp, answer given, whether it was correct, and score earned.

entity-relations-story.text: User Entity. The User is at the center of everything. They have progress records, make activity attempts, write notes, and may belong to organizations.
Course Entity. Courses contain lessons. Apprentice, Junior, Senior—each course has a hierarchy of chapters and lessons to complete.
Lesson Entity. Lessons are the core learning units. Each lesson contains multiple activities—quizzes, drag-drops, code challenges.
Activity Entity. Activities are interactive elements within lessons. Quizzes test knowledge, drag-drops build mental models, code challenges apply skills.

progress-flow-story.text: User Scrolls. The journey begins with a scroll. The user moves through lesson content, triggering the progress tracking system.
Observer Detects. IntersectionObserver fires when sections cross visibility thresholds. No expensive scroll listeners—just efficient threshold callbacks!
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker maintains the viewedSections set. Each visible section gets added, tracking exactly what's been seen.
Calculate Percentage. Progress percentage is calculated. Viewed sections divided by total sections equals completion. Simple math, powerful tracking!
DataService Saves. DataService receives the progress update and initiates the dual-write pattern. Two writes ensure dashboard optimization!
Subcollection Write. First write goes to the lessonProgress subcollection. Detailed data—viewed sections, timestamps, completion status.
Parent Field Write. Second write updates the parent courseProgress document. The lessons field gives dashboard a quick summary without deep queries!

dashboard-data-story.text: Stats Cards. The dashboard's stats cards show velocity, mastery, and streak. Each metric pulls from different data sources and calculations.
Velocity Calculation. Learning Velocity comes from lesson completion records. Lessons completed per week, scaled to a 0-100 score.
Mastery Calculation. Quiz Mastery averages scores from activityAttempts. Higher correct rates mean higher mastery percentages.
Streak Calculation. Streak counts consecutive active days. Data comes from dailyChallenges and user document's lastActive timestamp.
Lesson Progress Data. Velocity reads from lessonProgress collection. Completion timestamps let us calculate lessons per week.
Activity Attempts Data. Mastery reads from activityAttempts. Each attempt's score contributes to the average.
Daily Challenges Data. Streak calculation uses dailyChallenges. Each dated document proves that day's activity.
Course Grid. The course grid shows enrolled courses with progress bars. Data flows from courseProgress documents.
Progress Calculation. Course progress percentages come from the lessons summary field. Quick reads, no deep queries needed.
Course Progress Data. The courseProgress collection provides course-level summaries. Each enrolled course has a document here.
Activity Feed. The activity feed shows recent actions. Recent quiz attempts, lesson completions, and achievements.
Profile Bar. The profile bar displays user name and photo. Simple read from the user document.
User Document. The user document provides profile data and lastActive timestamp. Foundation for personalization!

auth-architecture-story.text: The User. Every authentication journey starts with a user. They want to log in, access their progress, and continue learning.
AuthService. AuthService is the gateway. It provides clean methods for login, registration, and logout—wrapping Firebase's complexity.
Firebase Auth. Firebase Auth handles the heavy lifting. Token management, session persistence, OAuth flows—all handled securely by Google's infrastructure.
Google OAuth. For Google login, Firebase connects to Google's OAuth servers. One-click authentication using existing Google accounts!
User Document. After authentication, we sync with Firestore. The user document stores profile info, roles, and organization memberships.

registration-flow-story.text: Registration Form. New users start with the registration form. They enter email, password, and display name—the essentials for creating an account.
Input Validation. Before hitting Firebase, we validate locally. Is the email formatted correctly? Is the password strong enough? Catch errors early!
Create Auth Account. createUserWithEmailAndPassword creates the Firebase Auth account. A unique UID is generated—the user's permanent identifier.
Create User Document. With auth complete, we create the Firestore user document. Profile info, default role, creation timestamp—everything initialized!
Welcome to Dashboard. Registration complete! Auth state changes, listeners fire, and the user lands on their brand new dashboard. Learning begins!

role-hierarchy-story.text: Admin Role. At the top sits the admin role. Full platform access—all courses, user management, organization controls. The keys to the kingdom!
Enterprise Role. Enterprise users belong to organizations. They inherit all standard user permissions PLUS access to partner courses for their org.
Standard User. Standard users form the base. Public courses, personal dashboard, progress tracking. Everything needed for self-paced learning!
Public Course Access. Standard users can access all public courses. Apprentice, Junior, Senior—the full curriculum is open to everyone who registers.
Partner Course Access. Enterprise users unlock partner courses. Organization-specific content tailored to their learning path and requirements.

access-check-story.text: Access Request. A user wants a protected resource. The RBAC system activates—a series of checks to determine if access is allowed.
Authentication Check. First gate: Is there a valid user session? No login means no access. Redirect to the login page immediately.
Admin Bypass. Admins get VIP treatment—they bypass all other checks! If role equals admin, access is granted immediately.
Public Course Check. Is this a public course? If yes, any authenticated user can access. No further checks needed!
Organization Check. For partner courses, verify organization membership. The user's organizations array must include the required org.
Access Granted!. All checks passed! The user has the right role, belongs to the right org, and has course access. Welcome in!

route-guard-story.text: Page Load. A user navigates to a page. RouteGuard intercepts before any content renders. Time for security checks!
Protected Check. First, isProtectedPage checks the URL. Marketing pages pass through. Dashboard and lessons require authentication.
Show Loading. For protected pages, we show a loading screen. Content stays hidden until auth state is confirmed. No flash of forbidden content!
Wait for Auth. waitForAuthState returns a promise. It resolves when Firebase Auth confirms the user's session status. Patient waiting!
RBAC Verification. With authentication confirmed, RBAC kicks in. Does this user have permission for this specific page and course?
Show Content. All checks passed! The loading screen fades, content appears, and the user can interact. RouteGuard's job is done!

org-access-story.text: Alice: Standard User. Meet Alice, a standard user. She can access all public courses—Apprentice and beyond. No organization membership.
Bob: Enterprise User. Bob is an enterprise user with Endless Opportunities. He gets public courses PLUS the exclusive EO Bootcamp content!
Organization Link. Bob's user document lists Endless Opportunities in his organizations array. This unlocks partner-specific content.
Partner Course. The EO Bootcamp is linked to Endless Opportunities. Only members of that org can access its lessons and activities.
Admin: Full Access. The admin can access everything! Public courses, all partner courses, every piece of content. Ultimate override authority!

tracking-overview-story.text: User Actions Begin. Progress tracking starts with user actions. Scrolling through content, answering quizzes, completing drag-drop activities.
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker watches scrolling behavior. It uses IntersectionObserver to detect which sections users have viewed.
ActivityTracker. ActivityTracker handles interactive elements. Quiz answers, drag completions, code challenges—every interaction is captured.
Data Persistence. Both trackers feed into DataService. Progress and activity data flows to Firestore for permanent storage.
UI Updates. As data changes, UI updates follow. Progress bars fill, completion indicators appear, toast notifications celebrate achievements!

section-discovery-story.text: Page Load. The lesson page loads. ProgressTracker needs to know what sections exist before it can track them.
Tracker Initializes. ProgressTracker.init kicks off the discovery process. Time to find all trackable sections on the page!
Query Selectors. querySelectorAll finds all elements with data-section attributes. These are our trackable content sections.
Sections Array. All discovered sections are stored in an array. This becomes the denominator for progress calculation.
Observer Setup. Finally, IntersectionObserver is created and attached to each section. Scroll tracking is now active!

scroll-observation-story.text: User Scrolls. The user scrolls through lesson content. Every movement could reveal new sections and advance progress.
Observer Monitors. IntersectionObserver watches visibility changes. Unlike scroll events, it only fires when thresholds are crossed. Efficient!
Visibility Check. When a section crosses 50 percent visibility, isIntersecting returns true. The section has been meaningfully viewed.
Mark as Viewed. The section ID is added to the viewedSections Set. Sets prevent duplicates—view a section twice, it still only counts once.
Debounced Save. Progress is saved with debouncing—multiple rapid views trigger just one Firestore write. Network efficiency!

activity-types-story.text: ActivityTracker Hub. ActivityTracker is the hub for all interactive elements. It discovers activities on page load and tracks their completion.
Quiz Activities. Quizzes use data-answer attributes to define correct answers. ActivityTracker validates user selections and records attempts.
Drag & Drop. Drag-drop activities use data-target to map items to zones. Drop an item in the right zone—activity complete!
Code Challenges. Code challenges have data-solution attributes. User code is compared against expected output for validation.
Firestore Storage. Every attempt is saved to Firestore's activityAttempts subcollection. Complete history of engagement!

offline-flow-story.text: Activity Attempt. A user completes an activity. But wait—what if they're offline? The internet isn't always reliable!
Connection Check. navigator.onLine tells us the connection status. Online? Save directly. Offline? Time for the queue!
Queue for Later. Offline attempts go into a queue. The activity is stored locally, waiting for reconnection.
LocalStorage Backup. The queue persists in LocalStorage. Even if the browser closes, queued attempts survive.
Connection Restored. The online event fires when connection returns. Time to sync those queued attempts!
Sync Process. syncQueuedAttempts processes the queue. Each pending attempt is saved to Firestore, then removed from the queue.

analytics-metrics-story.text: Raw Lesson Data. Analytics starts with raw data from Firestore. Lesson completion records tell us what content users have consumed.
Learning Velocity. calcVelocity computes learning speed. Lessons completed per week, multiplied by 20, gives a 0-100 velocity score.
Quiz Mastery. calcMastery averages quiz performance. Correct answers divided by total attempts—expressed as a percentage.
Active Streak. calcStreak counts consecutive days with activity. Miss a day? Streak resets. Consistency is rewarded!
Cognitive Score. The Cognitive Score combines all metrics with weights: 40 percent mastery, 30 percent velocity, 20 percent streak, 10 percent completion.

completion-flow-story.text: 90% Threshold. Progress hits 90 percent! This is the magic threshold—the lesson is essentially complete when this milestone is reached.
Already Complete?. Before celebrating, we check if the lesson was already marked complete. No duplicate celebrations!
Mark Complete. markLessonComplete sets the completion flag. This is a one-time operation per lesson.
Event Dispatch. A lessonComplete event broadcasts to the app. Other components can react—update UI, show notifications, unlock content.
Celebration Toast!. A toast notification appears celebrating the achievement. Visual feedback motivates continued learning!
Streak Updated. Finally, the user's streak is refreshed. Completing a lesson counts as daily activity. Keep that streak alive!

css-mapping-story.text: Marketing Styles. marketing.css handles landing pages and catalog pages. Hero sections, feature grids, testimonials—all the public-facing flair!
Auth Styles. auth.css styles login and registration forms. Centered cards, input fields, validation messages—clean and focused.
Dashboard Styles. dashboard.css creates the user hub layout. Sidebar navigation, stats cards, course grids, activity feeds.
Lesson Styles. lesson.css is the richest file. Content sections, code blocks, quizzes, drag-drop zones, progress indicators!

design-tokens-story.text: CSS Custom Properties. All design tokens live in the root selector as CSS custom properties. One source of truth for the entire design system!
Color Palette. Colors define the dark theme aesthetic. Primary backgrounds, accent colors, success and error states. Carefully chosen for contrast!
Background Colors. bg-primary is the darkest at hash 0a0a0f. Secondary and card backgrounds get progressively lighter. Depth through color!
Typography. Two font families define our look. Inter for body text—clean and readable. Space Grotesk for headings—bold and modern!
Effects & Transitions. Shadows and transitions bring the UI to life. Subtle shadows create depth. Smooth transitions make interactions feel polished.

animation-flow-story.text: Page Load Animations. Page load triggers entrance animations. Content fades in, elements stagger into view. First impressions matter!
Scroll Triggers. IntersectionObserver triggers scroll animations. As sections enter the viewport, they animate into visibility.
Anime.js Engine. Anime.js handles complex animations. Staggered reveals, elastic easing, timeline sequences—smooth and performant!
CSS Transitions. Simple interactions use CSS transitions. Hover effects, focus states, color changes—no JavaScript needed!
Fade In Effect. The signature fade-in: opacity zero to one, translateY 20 to zero. Content rises into view. Elegant and informative!

component-hierarchy-story.text: Card Component. Cards are our primary container pattern. A dark background with border, holding header, content, and footer sections.
Card Header. Card headers contain titles and icons. Consistent padding, bold typography—immediately scannable.
Card Content. Card content is flexible. Lists, paragraphs, charts, forms—any content fits within the card structure.
Button Component. Buttons have a base class with variants. Primary buttons stand out with accent colors. Secondary buttons are subtle.
Progress Bar. Progress bars show completion visually. A container with a fill element—width percentage equals progress percentage!

layout-patterns-story.text: Dashboard Layout. Dashboard uses a sidebar plus main content pattern. Fixed 240-pixel sidebar on the left, flex-grow main area on the right.
Sidebar Navigation. The sidebar provides persistent navigation. User profile, course links, settings—always accessible without scrolling.
Lesson Layout. Lesson pages have three columns: header, scrollable content, and progress nav on the right tracking scroll position.
Marketing Layout. Marketing pages use full-width sections. Hero at the top, feature grids, testimonials, call-to-action. Scroll storytelling!
Auth Layout. Auth pages center a single form card. Maximum 400-pixel width, vertically centered. Clean and focused on the task.

quiz-structure-story.text: Quiz Container. Every quiz starts with a container. The data-answer attribute holds the correct answer—hidden from the UI but accessible to JavaScript.
Question Text. The question is displayed prominently. Clear typography, adequate spacing—the user knows exactly what to answer.
Options Container. Options are grouped in a container. Each option has a data-value attribute that gets compared against data-answer.
Selected State. Clicking an option adds the selected class. Visual feedback with border color and background change—the user knows their choice!
Correct/Incorrect. After submission, correct and incorrect classes apply. Green for right, red for wrong. Immediate visual feedback!

breakpoints-story.text: Mobile First. Below 768 pixels is mobile territory. Single column layouts, hidden sidebars, stacked navigation. Touch-friendly targets!
Single Column. On mobile, content stacks vertically. No side-by-side layouts—everything flows top to bottom for easy scrolling.
Tablet Range. 768 to 1024 pixels is tablet territory. Two-column grids appear, sidebars become collapsible toggles.
Desktop Layout. 1024 to 1280 pixels is desktop range. Full layouts with visible sidebars, multi-column grids, expanded navigation.
Large Screens. Above 1280 pixels, we add max-width containers. Content doesn't stretch infinitely—readable line lengths are maintained.

color-contrast-story.text: Primary Background. bg-primary is the darkest background at hash 0a0a0f. Nearly black, it provides maximum contrast for text.
Primary Text. text-primary is light gray at hash e8e8f0. Against bg-primary, it achieves 15.2:1 contrast—well above WCAG requirements!
Secondary Text. text-secondary at hash a8a8b8 is slightly dimmer. 8.5:1 contrast for less prominent text—still highly readable.
Accent Colors. Accent colors provide visual interest. Purple primary, teal secondary, green success—each tested for adequate contrast.
Success Green. accent-success at hash 66bb6a achieves 8.1:1 contrast. Perfect for positive feedback without being harsh on dark backgrounds.

feature-overview-story.text: Partnership Portal. Welcome to the Partnership Portal! This admin-only system helps manage relationships with educational organizations, churches, foundations, and businesses.
Partner List. The partner list shows all organizations at a glance. Filter by type, status, or search by name. Your partnership CRM!
Partner Details. Each partner has a detailed view. Contact info, interaction history, attached documents, courses offered, and analytics.
Partner Types. Partners come in many forms—schools, churches, foundations, businesses, community organizations. Each type has unique needs.
Course Offerings. Partners can offer our four free courses, request custom curriculum, run live cohorts, or provide digital access to their members.

data-model-story.text: Firestore Structure. Partnership data lives in Firestore with a hierarchical structure. Top-level partners collection with nested subcollections.
Partners Collection. The partners collection holds all partner documents. Each organization gets one document identified by a unique ID.
Partner Document. Each partner document contains organization details, contact info, status, and metrics. But wait—there's more in subcollections!
Interactions. Every touchpoint is recorded in the interactions subcollection. Calls, meetings, emails, demos—complete relationship history.
Analytics Events. Time-series analytics in the analytics subcollection. Student enrollments, cohort completions, revenue—all trackable over time.

status-flow-story.text: Initial Contact. Every partnership begins with initial contact. A lead comes in, we add them to the system, and the journey begins!
Prospect Status. New partners start as prospects. Discovery calls, evaluating fit, understanding their needs. Building the relationship foundation.
Active Partnership. Agreement signed! Active partners have courses running, students enrolled, cohorts in progress. The partnership is live!
Paused Status. Sometimes partnerships pause. Between cohorts, budget reviews, organizational changes. Not ended—just on hold.
Churned. Churned means the partnership ended. Lost opportunity or completed engagement. But wait—re-engagement is possible!

interaction-flow-story.text: Admin User. An admin just had a call with a partner. Time to record it! Every touchpoint deserves documentation.
Interaction Form. The form captures details—type, title, description, outcome, next steps. Structured data for consistent tracking.
PartnerService. createInteraction in PartnerService handles the save. It updates multiple documents in a coordinated operation.
Save Interaction. The interaction document is created in the subcollection. Timestamp, admin ID, all details preserved.
Update Partner. The parent partner document updates too—lastInteractionAt, totalInteractions count. Quick dashboard metrics!

service-layer-story.text: UI Components. The frontend has several pages—partner list, detail view, forms, timeline, analytics dashboard. All need data!
Service Methods. PartnerService provides clean methods. getPartners, createPartner, createInteraction, uploadAttachment—organized API!
Firestore Backend. All methods ultimately talk to Firestore. Read operations fetch documents, write operations save changes.
File Storage. uploadAttachment uses Firebase Storage for files. The URL gets saved in Firestore with metadata. Best of both!

analytics-flow-story.text: Event Sources. Analytics events come from many sources. Student enrollments, cohort milestones, interactions, revenue—all tracked!
Event Storage. Events are stored with timestamps in the analytics subcollection. Time-series data ready for aggregation.
Aggregation. Events are grouped by date, type, and partner. Daily, weekly, monthly rollups for trend analysis.
Trend Calculation. Calculations reveal insights. Growth rates, completion percentages, revenue trends—metrics that drive decisions.
Visualizations. Charts bring data to life! Line charts for trends, bar charts for comparisons, pie charts for breakdowns. Visual insights!

page-structure-story.text: Admin Section. Partnership pages live under the admin section. Only users with admin role can access any of these features.
Partnerships Folder. The partnerships folder contains all portal pages. A logical grouping within the admin area.
Partner List. index.html is the main dashboard. All partners listed with filters, search, and quick actions.
Partner Detail. partner.html shows individual partner details. Timeline, attachments, courses, metrics—the complete picture.
Analytics Page. analytics.html provides the big picture. Aggregate metrics across all partnerships, trends, and insights.

service-story.text: Foundation: Firebase Config. Everything starts here. FirebaseApp initializes the Firebase SDK, establishing connections to Authentication and Firestore. This is loaded first on every page.
Authentication Layer. AuthService wraps Firebase Auth, managing user sessions, login flows, and auth state changes. It depends on FirebaseApp for the auth instance.
Data Access Layer. DataService handles all Firestore CRUD operations. It needs FirebaseApp for database access AND AuthService to scope queries to the current user.
Role-Based Access Control. RBACService checks user roles and permissions. It queries AuthService to get the current user, then checks their role against required permissions.
Progress Tracking. ProgressTracker uses IntersectionObserver to detect which content users have viewed. It saves progress via DataService and identifies users via AuthService.
Activity Completion. ActivityTracker records quiz answers and exercise completions. Like ProgressTracker, it writes to Firestore via DataService for authenticated users.
Route Protection. RouteGuard runs on page load to check if users can access the current page. It verifies authentication status AND role requirements before showing content.
Lesson Orchestration. Finally, LessonIntegration ties it all together on lesson pages. It coordinates ProgressTracker and ActivityTracker to create a seamless learning experience.

dataflow-story.text: User Initiates Action. It all starts with a user interaction—clicking a Complete Quiz button, scrolling past a section, or submitting a form. The browser captures this event.
Event Handler Catches It. The DOM event handler fires. This is JavaScript code in the page that responds to user actions and decides what to do next.
Service Method Called. The handler calls a service method like ProgressTracker.markComplete or ActivityTracker.submitAnswer. Business logic lives in these services, not in UI code.
Authentication Verified. Before writing data, the service checks AuthService.getCurrentUser. If no user is logged in, the action may be queued or rejected.
Data Written to Firestore. The service calls Firestore to persist the data. This might be updating a progress document, saving quiz answers, or logging activity.
Realtime Listener Triggers. Firestores onSnapshot listeners detect the change instantly. Any component subscribed to this data gets notified automatically.
Local State Updates. The listener callback updates the local state. This keeps the UI in sync with the database.
UI Reflects the Change. Finally, the UI re-renders to show the new state. A progress bar fills, a checkmark appears, or a success toast shows. The cycle is complete!

system-context-story.text: Students: The Users. Meet our users—students eager to learn software engineering. They access everything through a simple browser, connecting to our platform over standard HTTP.
Admins: The Managers. Admins manage the platform—creating courses, managing organizations, and monitoring learner progress. Same browser access, elevated permissions!
GitHub Pages Hosting. All requests flow through GitHub Pages. This CDN serves our static HTML files lightning-fast from edge locations worldwide. No server to manage!
Marketing Pages. Marketing pages are public—landing pages, course catalog, and pricing. No login required! Anyone can browse and discover what we offer.
Auth Pages. Auth pages handle login, registration, and password reset. This is where users become authenticated members of the platform.
Dashboard. The dashboard shows personalized progress—courses enrolled, completion percentages, learning velocity, and the cognitive score.
Lesson Pages. Lesson pages are where the magic happens. These interactive course content pages include quizzes, drag-drop activities, and progress tracking.
Blog. The blog features articles and tutorials. Some content is public, some requires login. A mix of marketing and education!
Shared JavaScript Services. All pages tap into our nine shared JavaScript services. These handle authentication, data storage, progress tracking, and more.
Firebase Authentication. Firebase Auth manages all user sessions. Email and password login, Google OAuth, password resets—it's all handled securely by Firebase.
Firestore Database. Finally, Firestore stores all user data—progress, quiz answers, notes, and more. Real-time sync keeps everything instantly up to date!

service-deps-story.text: FirebaseApp: The Foundation. Everything starts with FirebaseApp. This service initializes the Firebase SDK, giving all other services access to authentication and database.
AuthService Layer. AuthService wraps Firebase Auth with a clean API. It manages user sessions, login flows, and broadcasts auth state changes to the entire app.
DataService Operations. DataService is the workhorse. It needs both FirebaseApp for database access AND AuthService to scope every query to the current user.
RBACService. RBACService handles role-based access control. It checks if users have the right role and organization membership to access content.
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker watches what users scroll past using IntersectionObserver. It saves progress through DataService for the authenticated user.
ActivityTracker. ActivityTracker captures quiz answers and activity completions. Like ProgressTracker, it needs DataService and AuthService.
AnalyticsService. AnalyticsService calculates learning metrics—velocity, mastery, cognitive score. It reads data through DataService to compute these stats.
RouteGuard. RouteGuard protects pages that require login. It checks authentication status AND role permissions before showing any content.
LessonIntegration. LessonIntegration orchestrates everything on lesson pages. It coordinates AuthService, DataService, ProgressTracker, and ActivityTracker together!

data-flow-story.text: Browser: The Starting Point. Every journey begins in the browser. The user loads a page and starts interacting with buttons, forms, and scrollable content.
HTML Page Loads. The browser loads a static HTML page. This includes all the structure, styles, and JavaScript files needed to make it interactive.
UI Components Render. The HTML page renders interactive UI components—buttons, progress bars, quiz options. These are the touchpoints users interact with.
Event Handlers Fire. When users click, scroll, or type, event handlers spring into action. These JavaScript functions decide what happens next.
Services Process. Event handlers call service methods. This is where business logic lives—never in UI code. Services validate, transform, and route data.
State Management. Services update local state—window globals and component state. This triggers UI re-renders to show the latest data.
Firebase SDK. Services communicate with Firebase through the client-side SDK. It handles authentication tokens and database connections automatically.
Firestore Database. The Firebase SDK writes to Firestore in the cloud. Progress saved, quiz answers recorded, notes stored—all persisted permanently.
LocalStorage Cache. Some data is cached in LocalStorage for offline access and faster loading. This reduces database reads and improves performance!

page-services-story.text: Marketing Pages. Marketing pages are the lightest. They only load the navbar script for basic navigation. No authentication needed—anyone can browse!
navbar.js. navbar.js is the simplest service—just navigation handling. It's the only script marketing pages need to load!
Auth Pages. Login and register pages need more than navigation. They load AuthService for credential validation and account creation.
auth.js. auth.js handles all authentication—email login, Google OAuth, password reset, and session management. Many pages depend on it!
Dashboard. The dashboard is where users see their progress. It needs auth, data, analytics, and route protection—four services!
data-service.js. data-service.js handles all Firestore operations. Progress, activities, notes—anything that needs to persist goes through here.
analytics-service.js. analytics-service.js calculates learning metrics. Velocity, mastery, cognitive score—all the numbers on your dashboard!
route-guard.js. route-guard.js protects pages requiring login. If you're not authenticated, you get redirected before seeing anything.
Lesson Pages. Lesson pages are feature-rich! They need the most services—progress tracking, activity tracking, lesson orchestration, and more.
progress-tracker.js. progress-tracker.js uses IntersectionObserver to track what sections you've scrolled past. It auto-saves your reading progress!
activity-tracker.js. activity-tracker.js captures quiz answers and activity completions. Every interaction is logged for learning analytics.
lesson-integration.js. lesson-integration.js orchestrates everything on lesson pages. It coordinates all the trackers and services together!
Blog Pages. Blog pages are mostly public but can have some interactive features. They load navbar and the blog-specific service.
blog.js. blog.js handles blog-specific features—interactive elements, code highlighting, and optional auth for premium content.
Partner Courses. Partner courses are like lesson pages plus access control. Users must belong to the right organization to view content.
rbac.js. rbac.js checks organization membership and course access. Without the right permissions, you can't see partner content!

init-sequence-story.text: FirebaseApp.init(). The initialization chain begins! FirebaseApp.init runs first, setting up the Firebase SDK and making the database available to all other services.
AuthService.init(). Next, AuthService.init sets up the auth state listener. This tracks login status and notifies the app when users sign in or out.
DataService Ready. With auth ready, DataService becomes available. It can now query the database using FirebaseApp.getDb() for the authenticated user.
RBACService Ready. RBACService initializes in parallel with DataService. It needs both auth and database access to check user roles and permissions.
RouteGuard.init(). RouteGuard waits for both DataService and RBACService. It checks page access permissions and redirects unauthorized users.
ProgressTracker.init(). ProgressTracker.init sets up scroll observation using IntersectionObserver. It tracks which sections the user has viewed.
ActivityTracker.init(). ActivityTracker.init discovers interactive activities on the page—quizzes, drag-drops, code challenges. Ready to capture user interactions!

auth-service-story.text: AuthService: The Hub. AuthService is the authentication hub. It wraps Firebase Auth with a clean, consistent API for the rest of the application to use.
register() Method. The register method creates new accounts. It validates input, calls Firebase, updates the profile with display name, and creates the user document.
loginWithEmail() Method. loginWithEmail handles traditional email and password authentication. Users enter their credentials and Firebase validates them securely.
loginWithGoogle() Method. loginWithGoogle opens the OAuth popup. One click and users are authenticated with their Google account. Fast and secure!
logout() Method. The logout method signs the user out of Firebase and clears all cached authentication state. Clean and simple!
currentUser Property. The currentUser property caches the authenticated user. Any component can check login status instantly without waiting for Firebase.
onAuthStateChanged(). onAuthStateChanged broadcasts login and logout events. Components subscribe to react when authentication status changes.
Firebase Auth Backend. Firebase Auth is the backend service that handles all the heavy lifting—password hashing, token generation, OAuth flows, and secure session management.
User Document. After registration, a user document is created in Firestore. This stores profile data, roles, and organization membership for the app to use.

data-service-story.text: DataService: Central Hub. DataService is the central data hub. All Firestore operations flow through here—progress, activities, notes, enrollments, and more.
Progress Operations. Progress ops handle lesson and course completion. saveLessonProgress, getCourseProgress—everything about tracking what users have learned.
Activity Operations. Activity ops record quiz answers, drag-drop completions, and code challenges. Every attempt is logged for analytics.
Enrollment Operations. Enrollment ops manage course registrations. Users enroll in courses, and the system tracks their enrollment status and access dates.
courseProgress Collection. courseProgress stores high-level course completion data. Percentage complete, last accessed timestamp, and overall course status.
lessonProgress Collection. lessonProgress tracks individual lessons. Which sections were viewed, time spent, scroll position, and completion status.
activityAttempts Collection. activityAttempts records every quiz answer and activity interaction. Timestamps, answers, scores—all preserved for learning analytics.

tracking-services-story.text: IntersectionObserver API. The browser's IntersectionObserver API powers scroll tracking. It efficiently detects when sections enter or leave the viewport.
DOM Events. DOM Events trigger activity tracking. Clicks, changes, and other user interactions fire events that ActivityTracker listens for.
ProgressTracker Service. ProgressTracker uses IntersectionObserver to watch sections. When 50 percent of a section is visible, it's marked as viewed.
ActivityTracker Service. ActivityTracker listens for DOM events—clicks on quiz options, drops in drag zones. Every interaction is captured and scored.
viewedSections Set. viewedSections is a Set that stores which sections have been scrolled to. It prevents duplicate tracking and enables efficient lookups.
completedActivities State. completedActivities tracks which activities the user has finished. It stores activity IDs and their completion states in memory.
lessonProgress Firestore. viewedSections data persists to Firestore's lessonProgress collection. Even if you close the browser, your progress is saved!
activityAttempts Firestore. Activity completion data flows to Firestore's activityAttempts collection. Every quiz answer and interaction is permanently recorded.

analytics-pipeline-story.text: Progress Data Input. Analytics starts with raw data—lesson completion records from Firestore. This tells us how much content users have consumed.
Activity Data Input. Quiz attempts and scores feed into the pipeline separately. This measures how well users understand the material, not just consumption.
calculateVelocity(). calculateVelocity computes learning speed. Lessons completed divided by weeks active, scaled to a 0-100 score. Fast learners score high!
calculateMastery(). calculateMastery averages quiz scores. Correct answers divided by total attempts gives us a mastery percentage.
Learning Velocity Score. Learning Velocity is the final speed metric. Lessons per week times 20, capped at 100. It shows how quickly a learner is progressing.
Quiz Mastery Score. Quiz Mastery shows understanding depth. High scores mean the learner truly grasps concepts, not just skimming through content.
calculateCognitive(). calculateCognitive combines all metrics! 40 percent mastery, 30 percent velocity, 20 percent streak, 10 percent completion. The formula for learning excellence!
Final Cognitive Score. The Cognitive Score is the ultimate learning metric. One number that represents overall learning effectiveness. Higher is better!

access-control-story.text: Page Request. A user wants to access a protected resource. Maybe a partner course or the admin dashboard. Let's see if they're allowed!
Authentication Check. First checkpoint—is the user signed in? No authentication means redirect to login. Can't proceed without credentials!
Redirect to Login. If the user isn't authenticated, they're redirected to the login page. After signing in, they'll return to where they wanted to go.
hasRole() Check. If authenticated, we check the user's role using hasRole(). Are they admin, enterprise, or standard user? Different roles unlock different resources.
belongsToOrg() Check. belongsToOrg() verifies organization membership. For partner courses, users must belong to the sponsoring organization.
canAccessCourse() Check. canAccessCourse() is the final gate. It verifies the user has permission to access this specific course content.
Access Granted!. All checks passed! The user can access the content. Page renders, learning begins. The flow is complete!

page-hierarchy-story.text: All Page Types. The SWE Hackers platform has ten distinct page types. They're organized by access requirements—from fully public to highly restricted.
Public Pages Category. Public pages need no authentication. Anyone can browse these without signing in.
Marketing Pages. Marketing includes landing pages, course catalog, and pricing. These attract new users with no barriers to entry.
Auth Pages. Auth pages handle login, registration, and password reset. They're public so users can create accounts and sign in.
Protected Pages Category. Protected pages require authentication. You must be logged in to see these!
Dashboard. The dashboard is your personal hub. It shows enrolled courses, progress metrics, and learning analytics.
Lesson Pages. Lesson pages are where the actual learning happens. Interactive content, quizzes, and progress tracking.
RBAC Protected Category. RBAC pages add role and organization checks on top of authentication. Extra security layers!
Partner Courses. Partner courses are organization-specific. You must belong to the sponsoring organization AND have course access.
Admin Pages. Admin pages require the admin role. Only platform administrators can access user management and system settings.

dashboard-flow-story.text: Page Load Begins. User navigates to the dashboard. The browser requests the page, and our loading sequence kicks into gear.
Show Loading Screen. First, we show a loading screen. Content is hidden until we confirm the user is authenticated. No flashing of unauthorized content!
Init Services. While the loading screen shows, services initialize—Firebase SDK, AuthService, and DataService get ready.
Auth Check. Services are ready! Now we check authentication. Is there a valid user session? If not, redirect to login.
Load User Profile. Auth confirmed! We fetch the user profile—display name, enrolled courses, preferences. This happens in parallel with analytics.
Load Analytics. Simultaneously, we calculate learning metrics—velocity, mastery, streak, cognitive score. All computed from progress data.
Stats Cards Render. Analytics flow to the stats cards. Velocity, mastery, and streak scores render with animated progress indicators.
Course Grid Render. User profile data populates the course grid. Each enrolled course shows progress percentage and last activity date.

lesson-architecture-story.text: LessonIntegration Orchestrator. LessonIntegration orchestrates everything on lesson pages. It coordinates progress tracking, activity handling, and UI updates.
Scroll Events. As users scroll, browser events fire. These scroll events trigger the progress tracking system.
ProgressTracker Service. ProgressTracker uses IntersectionObserver for efficient scroll detection. When 50 percent of a section is visible, it counts as viewed.
Save Progress. Progress changes trigger Firestore writes. Your reading progress is persisted so you can pick up where you left off.
Progress Bar Updates. The progress bar updates in real-time as you scroll. Visual feedback shows exactly how much of the lesson you've covered.
Quiz Click Events. When you click a quiz answer, interaction events fire. Time to validate your knowledge!
lesson.js UI Handler. lesson.js handles the UI side of interactions—showing feedback, highlighting correct answers, playing animations.
ActivityTracker Service. ActivityTracker handles all interactive elements—quizzes, drag-drop, code challenges. Every completion is saved to Firestore.
Lesson Complete Toast. When progress hits 90 percent, the lesson is marked complete. A celebration toast appears, and the next lesson unlocks!

partner-flow-story.text: Course Request. A user tries to access a partner course. These are organization-specific—not everyone can get in. Let's check the credentials!
Auth Check Gate. First gate—authentication. Is the user logged in? If not, we redirect to login.
Redirect to Login. No authentication? Redirect to login! After signing in, the user will return to try again.
Load Permissions. User is authenticated! Now we fetch their RBAC data—roles, organization memberships, and course access lists.
Organization Check. Second gate—organization membership. The user must belong to the organization that sponsors this course.
Course Access Check. Final gate—course access. Does the user have this specific course in their access list? All gates cleared means access granted!
Access Granted - Render. All checks passed! The lesson content renders. Learning begins. The multi-layer security keeps content protected.

collection-hierarchy-story.text: Firestore Root. Welcome to Firestore—our cloud database! It uses a hierarchical structure with collections, documents, and nested subcollections.
Users Collection. The users collection is our main entry point. Every registered user gets a document here, identified by their Firebase Auth UID.
Courses Collection. The courses collection stores course metadata. This is optional—mainly used for admin features and catalog displays.
User Document. Each user document stores profile info, role, and organization memberships. But that's just the start—subcollections hold the real data!
Course Progress. The courseProgress subcollection tracks progress per course. Each course the user enrolls in gets its own document here.
Daily Challenges. dailyChallenges tracks completed challenges by date. This powers the streak calculation and daily engagement metrics.
User Notes. The notes subcollection stores user notes per lesson. Personal annotations that persist across sessions.
Course Document. Each course progress document contains summary data plus nested subcollections for detailed tracking.
Lesson Progress. Nested even deeper—lessonProgress tracks individual lessons. Viewed sections, completion status, last visit time. Granular tracking!
Activity Attempts. Every quiz answer, drag-drop completion, and code challenge is recorded in activityAttempts. Complete history of engagement!
Lesson Document. Each lesson document stores detailed progress—viewed sections array, timestamps, scroll position, and completion percentage.
Attempt Document. Individual attempt documents record each interaction—timestamp, answer given, whether it was correct, and score earned.

entity-relations-story.text: User Entity. The User is at the center of everything. They have progress records, make activity attempts, write notes, and may belong to organizations.
Course Entity. Courses contain lessons. Apprentice, Junior, Senior—each course has a hierarchy of chapters and lessons to complete.
Lesson Entity. Lessons are the core learning units. Each lesson contains multiple activities—quizzes, drag-drops, code challenges.
Activity Entity. Activities are interactive elements within lessons. Quizzes test knowledge, drag-drops build mental models, code challenges apply skills.

progress-flow-story.text: User Scrolls. The journey begins with a scroll. The user moves through lesson content, triggering the progress tracking system.
Observer Detects. IntersectionObserver fires when sections cross visibility thresholds. No expensive scroll listeners—just efficient threshold callbacks!
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker maintains the viewedSections set. Each visible section gets added, tracking exactly what's been seen.
Calculate Percentage. Progress percentage is calculated. Viewed sections divided by total sections equals completion. Simple math, powerful tracking!
DataService Saves. DataService receives the progress update and initiates the dual-write pattern. Two writes ensure dashboard optimization!
Subcollection Write. First write goes to the lessonProgress subcollection. Detailed data—viewed sections, timestamps, completion status.
Parent Field Write. Second write updates the parent courseProgress document. The lessons field gives dashboard a quick summary without deep queries!

dashboard-data-story.text: Stats Cards. The dashboard's stats cards show velocity, mastery, and streak. Each metric pulls from different data sources and calculations.
Velocity Calculation. Learning Velocity comes from lesson completion records. Lessons completed per week, scaled to a 0-100 score.
Mastery Calculation. Quiz Mastery averages scores from activityAttempts. Higher correct rates mean higher mastery percentages.
Streak Calculation. Streak counts consecutive active days. Data comes from dailyChallenges and user document's lastActive timestamp.
Lesson Progress Data. Velocity reads from lessonProgress collection. Completion timestamps let us calculate lessons per week.
Activity Attempts Data. Mastery reads from activityAttempts. Each attempt's score contributes to the average.
Daily Challenges Data. Streak calculation uses dailyChallenges. Each dated document proves that day's activity.
Course Grid. The course grid shows enrolled courses with progress bars. Data flows from courseProgress documents.
Progress Calculation. Course progress percentages come from the lessons summary field. Quick reads, no deep queries needed.
Course Progress Data. The courseProgress collection provides course-level summaries. Each enrolled course has a document here.
Activity Feed. The activity feed shows recent actions. Recent quiz attempts, lesson completions, and achievements.
Profile Bar. The profile bar displays user name and photo. Simple read from the user document.
User Document. The user document provides profile data and lastActive timestamp. Foundation for personalization!

auth-architecture-story.text: The User. Every authentication journey starts with a user. They want to log in, access their progress, and continue learning.
AuthService. AuthService is the gateway. It provides clean methods for login, registration, and logout—wrapping Firebase's complexity.
Firebase Auth. Firebase Auth handles the heavy lifting. Token management, session persistence, OAuth flows—all handled securely by Google's infrastructure.
Google OAuth. For Google login, Firebase connects to Google's OAuth servers. One-click authentication using existing Google accounts!
User Document. After authentication, we sync with Firestore. The user document stores profile info, roles, and organization memberships.

registration-flow-story.text: Registration Form. New users start with the registration form. They enter email, password, and display name—the essentials for creating an account.
Input Validation. Before hitting Firebase, we validate locally. Is the email formatted correctly? Is the password strong enough? Catch errors early!
Create Auth Account. createUserWithEmailAndPassword creates the Firebase Auth account. A unique UID is generated—the user's permanent identifier.
Create User Document. With auth complete, we create the Firestore user document. Profile info, default role, creation timestamp—everything initialized!
Welcome to Dashboard. Registration complete! Auth state changes, listeners fire, and the user lands on their brand new dashboard. Learning begins!

role-hierarchy-story.text: Admin Role. At the top sits the admin role. Full platform access—all courses, user management, organization controls. The keys to the kingdom!
Enterprise Role. Enterprise users belong to organizations. They inherit all standard user permissions PLUS access to partner courses for their org.
Standard User. Standard users form the base. Public courses, personal dashboard, progress tracking. Everything needed for self-paced learning!
Public Course Access. Standard users can access all public courses. Apprentice, Junior, Senior—the full curriculum is open to everyone who registers.
Partner Course Access. Enterprise users unlock partner courses. Organization-specific content tailored to their learning path and requirements.

access-check-story.text: Access Request. A user wants a protected resource. The RBAC system activates—a series of checks to determine if access is allowed.
Authentication Check. First gate: Is there a valid user session? No login means no access. Redirect to the login page immediately.
Admin Bypass. Admins get VIP treatment—they bypass all other checks! If role equals admin, access is granted immediately.
Public Course Check. Is this a public course? If yes, any authenticated user can access. No further checks needed!
Organization Check. For partner courses, verify organization membership. The user's organizations array must include the required org.
Access Granted!. All checks passed! The user has the right role, belongs to the right org, and has course access. Welcome in!

route-guard-story.text: Page Load. A user navigates to a page. RouteGuard intercepts before any content renders. Time for security checks!
Protected Check. First, isProtectedPage checks the URL. Marketing pages pass through. Dashboard and lessons require authentication.
Show Loading. For protected pages, we show a loading screen. Content stays hidden until auth state is confirmed. No flash of forbidden content!
Wait for Auth. waitForAuthState returns a promise. It resolves when Firebase Auth confirms the user's session status. Patient waiting!
RBAC Verification. With authentication confirmed, RBAC kicks in. Does this user have permission for this specific page and course?
Show Content. All checks passed! The loading screen fades, content appears, and the user can interact. RouteGuard's job is done!

org-access-story.text: Alice: Standard User. Meet Alice, a standard user. She can access all public courses—Apprentice and beyond. No organization membership.
Bob: Enterprise User. Bob is an enterprise user with Endless Opportunities. He gets public courses PLUS the exclusive EO Bootcamp content!
Organization Link. Bob's user document lists Endless Opportunities in his organizations array. This unlocks partner-specific content.
Partner Course. The EO Bootcamp is linked to Endless Opportunities. Only members of that org can access its lessons and activities.
Admin: Full Access. The admin can access everything! Public courses, all partner courses, every piece of content. Ultimate override authority!

tracking-overview-story.text: User Actions Begin. Progress tracking starts with user actions. Scrolling through content, answering quizzes, completing drag-drop activities.
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker watches scrolling behavior. It uses IntersectionObserver to detect which sections users have viewed.
ActivityTracker. ActivityTracker handles interactive elements. Quiz answers, drag completions, code challenges—every interaction is captured.
Data Persistence. Both trackers feed into DataService. Progress and activity data flows to Firestore for permanent storage.
UI Updates. As data changes, UI updates follow. Progress bars fill, completion indicators appear, toast notifications celebrate achievements!

section-discovery-story.text: Page Load. The lesson page loads. ProgressTracker needs to know what sections exist before it can track them.
Tracker Initializes. ProgressTracker.init kicks off the discovery process. Time to find all trackable sections on the page!
Query Selectors. querySelectorAll finds all elements with data-section attributes. These are our trackable content sections.
Sections Array. All discovered sections are stored in an array. This becomes the denominator for progress calculation.
Observer Setup. Finally, IntersectionObserver is created and attached to each section. Scroll tracking is now active!

scroll-observation-story.text: User Scrolls. The user scrolls through lesson content. Every movement could reveal new sections and advance progress.
Observer Monitors. IntersectionObserver watches visibility changes. Unlike scroll events, it only fires when thresholds are crossed. Efficient!
Visibility Check. When a section crosses 50 percent visibility, isIntersecting returns true. The section has been meaningfully viewed.
Mark as Viewed. The section ID is added to the viewedSections Set. Sets prevent duplicates—view a section twice, it still only counts once.
Debounced Save. Progress is saved with debouncing—multiple rapid views trigger just one Firestore write. Network efficiency!

activity-types-story.text: ActivityTracker Hub. ActivityTracker is the hub for all interactive elements. It discovers activities on page load and tracks their completion.
Quiz Activities. Quizzes use data-answer attributes to define correct answers. ActivityTracker validates user selections and records attempts.
Drag & Drop. Drag-drop activities use data-target to map items to zones. Drop an item in the right zone—activity complete!
Code Challenges. Code challenges have data-solution attributes. User code is compared against expected output for validation.
Firestore Storage. Every attempt is saved to Firestore's activityAttempts subcollection. Complete history of engagement!

offline-flow-story.text: Activity Attempt. A user completes an activity. But wait—what if they're offline? The internet isn't always reliable!
Connection Check. navigator.onLine tells us the connection status. Online? Save directly. Offline? Time for the queue!
Queue for Later. Offline attempts go into a queue. The activity is stored locally, waiting for reconnection.
LocalStorage Backup. The queue persists in LocalStorage. Even if the browser closes, queued attempts survive.
Connection Restored. The online event fires when connection returns. Time to sync those queued attempts!
Sync Process. syncQueuedAttempts processes the queue. Each pending attempt is saved to Firestore, then removed from the queue.

analytics-metrics-story.text: Raw Lesson Data. Analytics starts with raw data from Firestore. Lesson completion records tell us what content users have consumed.
Learning Velocity. calcVelocity computes learning speed. Lessons completed per week, multiplied by 20, gives a 0-100 velocity score.
Quiz Mastery. calcMastery averages quiz performance. Correct answers divided by total attempts—expressed as a percentage.
Active Streak. calcStreak counts consecutive days with activity. Miss a day? Streak resets. Consistency is rewarded!
Cognitive Score. The Cognitive Score combines all metrics with weights: 40 percent mastery, 30 percent velocity, 20 percent streak, 10 percent completion.

completion-flow-story.text: 90% Threshold. Progress hits 90 percent! This is the magic threshold—the lesson is essentially complete when this milestone is reached.
Already Complete?. Before celebrating, we check if the lesson was already marked complete. No duplicate celebrations!
Mark Complete. markLessonComplete sets the completion flag. This is a one-time operation per lesson.
Event Dispatch. A lessonComplete event broadcasts to the app. Other components can react—update UI, show notifications, unlock content.
Celebration Toast!. A toast notification appears celebrating the achievement. Visual feedback motivates continued learning!
Streak Updated. Finally, the user's streak is refreshed. Completing a lesson counts as daily activity. Keep that streak alive!

css-mapping-story.text: Marketing Styles. marketing.css handles landing pages and catalog pages. Hero sections, feature grids, testimonials—all the public-facing flair!
Auth Styles. auth.css styles login and registration forms. Centered cards, input fields, validation messages—clean and focused.
Dashboard Styles. dashboard.css creates the user hub layout. Sidebar navigation, stats cards, course grids, activity feeds.
Lesson Styles. lesson.css is the richest file. Content sections, code blocks, quizzes, drag-drop zones, progress indicators!

design-tokens-story.text: CSS Custom Properties. All design tokens live in the root selector as CSS custom properties. One source of truth for the entire design system!
Color Palette. Colors define the dark theme aesthetic. Primary backgrounds, accent colors, success and error states. Carefully chosen for contrast!
Background Colors. bg-primary is the darkest at hash 0a0a0f. Secondary and card backgrounds get progressively lighter. Depth through color!
Typography. Two font families define our look. Inter for body text—clean and readable. Space Grotesk for headings—bold and modern!
Effects & Transitions. Shadows and transitions bring the UI to life. Subtle shadows create depth. Smooth transitions make interactions feel polished.

animation-flow-story.text: Page Load Animations. Page load triggers entrance animations. Content fades in, elements stagger into view. First impressions matter!
Scroll Triggers. IntersectionObserver triggers scroll animations. As sections enter the viewport, they animate into visibility.
